docs.snippet: BOGOTA, Colombia, May 27 -- Five South American nations -- Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru -- last night formally joined in an association intended to develop into an Andean common market.
docs.lead_paragraph: BOGOTA, Colombia, May 27 -- Five South American nations -- Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru -- last night formally joined in an association intended to develop into an Andean common market.

docs.snippet: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, June 1 -- Governor Rockefeller today called off his visit to Venezuela, only 24 hours before it was to begin, at the request of that country's President, Dr. Rafael Caldera.
docs.lead_paragraph: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, June 1 -- Governor Rockefeller today called off his visit to Venezuela, only 24 hours before it was to begin, at the request of that country's President, Dr. Rafael Caldera.
docs.abstract: Rockefeller calls off visit at request of Caldera; Caldera indicates visit would set off disturbances and should be postponed to more propitious time; Venezuela indicates it will conduct study of US-Latin Amer relations as more systematic and less pub approach than Rockefeller visit; White House silent

headline.main: ROCKEFELLER VISIT TO VENEZUELA OFF IN PROTEST THREAT; Caldera Asks Postponement -- Governor Says 'Forces' Seek to Disrupt Tour

docs.snippet: President Nixon has the unpleasant alternative of canceling the remainder of Governor Rockefeller's Latin mission or allowing the Governor and his party to proceed doggedly, at considerable physical risk, with visits more likely to worsen than to...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Nixon has the unpleasant alternative of canceling the remainder of Governor Rockefeller's Latin mission or allowing the Governor and his party to proceed doggedly, at considerable physical risk, with visits more likely to worsen than to bolster United States ties with the peoples of the other Americas.
docs.abstract: ed urges Nixon cancel remainder of mission

keywords.name: subject

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, June 3 -Some Latin-American diplomats said privately here today that the violence that has plagued most stops of Governor Rockefeller's first two trips to Central and South America might serve to call United States attention to frustrated...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 3 -Some Latin-American diplomats said privately here today that the violence that has plagued most stops of Governor Rockefeller's first two trips to Central and South America might serve to call United States attention to frustrated expectations of economic and social development in Latin America.

docs.snippet: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 4 -- The Latin American Foreign Ministers have adopted a "common position" proposing "new bases" for inter-American economic and social cooperation that go beyond the Alliance for Progress.
docs.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 4 -- The Latin American Foreign Ministers have adopted a "common position" proposing "new bases" for inter-American economic and social cooperation that go beyond the Alliance for Progress.
docs.abstract: Latin-Amer Foreign Mins outline 'common position' proposing new bases for inter-Amer econ and soc cooperation in memorandum prepared at Vina del Mar, Chile, conf; memorandum deals mainly with econ growth and is to be delivered to Nixon by Chilean Min Valdes shortly; covers scattered complaints encountered by Rockefeller from Latin Amer leaders; cautions that its proposals should not be regarded as antagonistic or negative towards US but as part of necessary effort to overcome causes of friction; calls for curtailment of barriers limiting Latin-Amer countries' ability to export goods to US; urges private investment not be considered as assistance or computed as part of financial cooperation for development; scores existence of pol and mil conditions for aid; neglects to mention term Alliance for Progress, which Latin-Amer leaders reptdly consider as Dem phrase, but insists on validity of underlying multilateral agreements on which Alliance is based; cites lack of adequate US implementation of and attention to programs; calls on US to adopt certain 'operative measures' in internatl trade, financing, investments, transportation and 'invisible' transfers, tech cooperation and scientific and tech development; measures detailed

headline.main: LATIN MINISTERS URGE NEW SET-UP IN TRADE AND AID; Outline for Inter-American Cooperation Goes Beyond the Alliance for Progress

docs.snippet: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 5 -- Cuba won a surprise victory in the Economic and Social Council today with her election to the governing body of the United Nations Development Program over the opposition of all her Latin-American neighbors.
docs.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 5 -- Cuba won a surprise victory in the Economic and Social Council today with her election to the governing body of the United Nations Development Program over the opposition of all her Latin-American neighbors.
docs.abstract: Gentlemen's agreement under which members accept nominations by regional blocs in elections where votes cannot be checked is breached by ECOSOC election of Cuba to Development Program governing council when Latin-Amer group had chosen Argentina

headline.main: Cuba Wins a Surprise Victory, Seat on U.N. Development Body

byline.original: By SAM POPE BREWERSpecial to The New York Times

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, June 5 -- There is "some discontent" in Latin America over United States policies, Secretary of State William P. Rogers conceded today. He pledged that the Nixon Administration would do "all we can" to improve the situation.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 5 -- There is "some discontent" in Latin America over United States policies, Secretary of State William P. Rogers conceded today. He pledged that the Nixon Administration would do "all we can" to improve the situation.
docs.abstract: Rogers concedes there is 'some discontent' over US policies in Latin Amer, State Dept news conf; pledges Nixon Adm will do all it can to improve situation; says there is no part of world more important to US and that deterioration in relations would be tragic; acknowledges disappointment with hostile demonstrations connected with Rockefeller mission; says he and Rockefeller agree that demonstrations do not represent deep-seated feelings on part of pub generally or by Govt officials; says he thinks 'some' Cong leaders are aware of resentment over US tariff policies and rigid conditions attached to aid; concedes he is not sure Cong as whole understands; pledges rept, drawn up at Vina del Mar conf, will be given 'careful' consideration

headline.main: EFFORTS TO EASE LATIN DISCONTENT PROMISED BY U.S.; Rogers Asserts Government Will Do All It Can to Avert a 'Tragic' Strain in Ties EFFORTS TO HELP LATINS PLEDGED
